metadata.synopsis: Auschwitz survivor and retired prostitute Madame Rosa (Simone Signoret) has become a caretaker for the children of other prostitutes. With her physical and mental health declining, Rosa begins returning her charges to their parents' care. However, she has grown attached to the only unclaimed child, Momo (Samy Ben Youb), a 14-year-old Arab boy whose parents disappeared years ago. Still tormented by memories of the Holocaust, Rosa becomes increasingly convinced the Gestapo is coming for her.

reviews: This is a movie definitely worth seeing for Signoret's portrayal of a very human old woman, a type not often selected in the cinema for heroine stature.
Simone Signoret -- with her perfect image, performance, humanity, and pathos -- makes and saves the film. [Full Review in Spanish]
This melodrama, which won Foreign Language Oscar, about an aging prostitute taking care of children, is mediocre, but Simone Signoret gives a dominant, utterly compelling performance.
Mawkish as hell, but Signoret redeems much of it.
A fine film celebrating the beauty of the human spirit.
